sn35.136:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, gods and humans like sights, they love them and enjoy them.

sn35.136:1.2.eng: But when sights perish, fade away, and cease, gods and humans live in suffering.

sn35.136:1.8.eng: ideas, they love them and enjoy them.

sn35.136:1.9.eng: But when ideas perish, fade away, and cease, gods and humans live in suffering.

sn35.136:1.10.pli: Tathāgato ca kho, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho rūpānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā na rūpārāmo na rūparato na rūpasammudito.
sn35.136:1.10.eng: The Realized One has truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sights, so he doesn’t like, love, or enjoy them.

sn35.136:1.11.eng: When sights perish, fade away, and cease, the Realized One lives happily.

sn35.136:1.12.eng: The Realized One has truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sounds …

sn35.136:1.16.pli: dhammānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā na dhammārāmo, na dhammarato, na dhammasammudito.
sn35.136:1.16.eng: ideas, so he doesn’t like, love, or enjoy them.

sn35.136:1.17.eng: When ideas perish, fade away, and cease, the Realized One lives happily.”

sn35.136:1.18.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn35.136:1.19.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn35.136:1.19.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn35.136:2.2.eng: touches and ideas, the lot of them—

sn35.136:2.4.eng: as long as you can say that they exist.
sn35.136:2.4.comm: Notice the positive association of “exist” (atthi).

sn35.136:3.1.eng: For all the world with its gods,

sn35.136:3.2.eng: this is what they deem happiness.

sn35.136:3.4.eng: is deemed as suffering for them.

sn35.136:4.1.eng: The noble ones have seen that happiness

sn35.136:4.2.eng: is the cessation of substantial reality.

sn35.136:4.3.eng: This insight by those who see

sn35.136:5.2.eng: the noble ones say is suffering.

sn35.136:5.4.eng: the noble ones know as happiness.

sn35.136:6.1.eng: See, this teaching is hard to understand,

sn35.136:6.3.eng: There is darkness for the shrouded;

sn35.136:6.4.eng: blackness for those who don’t see.

sn35.136:7.2.eng: like light for those who see.

sn35.136:7.3.eng: Though close, they do not understand,

sn35.136:7.4.eng: the seekers inexpert in the teaching.
sn35.136:7.4.comm: Bodhi translates “dullards”, evidently reading magā (“beasts”) and taking to mean “fools”. However, I can’t find support for this sense in Pali or Sanskrit. The commentary explains it as those inexpert in knowing what is the path and what is not the path, apparently taking maggā as a truncation of maggāmagga. I read as a secondary derivative from magga in the old sense “seeking”, with the -a suffix making it the agentive “seekers”.

sn35.136:8.1.eng: They’re mired in desire for continued existence,

sn35.136:8.2.eng: flowing along the stream of lives,

sn35.136:8.4.eng: this teaching isn’t easy for them to understand.

sn35.136:9.1.eng: Who, apart from the noble ones,

sn35.136:9.2.eng: is qualified to understand this state?

sn35.137:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, gods and humans like sights, they love them and enjoy them.

sn35.137:1.2.eng: But when sights perish, fade away, and cease, gods and humans live in suffering. …

sn35.137:1.9.pli: Tathāgato ca, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho rūpānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā na rūpārāmo na rūparato na rūpasammudito.
sn35.137:1.9.eng: The Realized One has truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sights, so he doesn’t like, love, or enjoy them.

sn35.137:1.10.eng: When sights perish, fade away, and cease, the Realized One lives happily. …”

sn35.137:1.15.pli: dhammānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā na dhammārāmo na dhammarato na dhammasammudito.

sn35.138:1.2.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.138:1.2.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.138:1.4.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṃ; taṃ pajahatha.
sn35.138:1.4.eng: The eye isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.138:1.5.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati …pe…
sn35.138:1.5.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.138:1.7.pli: Sā vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissati …pe…

sn35.138:1.8.eng: mind isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.138:1.9.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.138:1.9.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.138:1.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yaṃ imasmiṃ jetavane tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ taṃ jano hareyya vā ḍaheyya vā yathāpaccayaṃ vā kareyya, api nu tumhākaṃ evamassa:
sn35.138:1.10.eng: Suppose a person was to carry off the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in this Jeta’s Grove, or burn them, or do what they want with them. Would you think:

sn35.138:1.11.pli: ‘amhe jano harati vā ḍahati vā yathāpaccayaṃ vā karotī’”ti?
sn35.138:1.11.eng: ‘This person is carrying us off, burning us, or doing what they want with us’?”

sn35.138:1.14.pli: “Na hi no etaṃ, bhante, attā vā attaniyaṃ vā”ti.
sn35.138:1.14.eng: Because  to us that’s neither self nor belonging to self.”

sn35.138:1.15.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhu na tumhākaṃ; taṃ pajahatha.
sn35.138:1.15.eng: “In the same way, the eye isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.138:1.16.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati …pe…
sn35.138:1.16.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.138:1.18.pli: Sā vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissati …pe…

sn35.138:1.19.eng: mind isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.138:1.20.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissatī”ti.
sn35.138:1.20.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.”

sn35.139:1.2.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.139:1.2.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.139:1.4.eng: Sights aren’t yours: give them up.

sn35.139:1.5.pli: te pajahatha. Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.
sn35.139:1.5.eng: Giving them up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.139:1.10.eng: and ideas aren’t yours: give them up.

sn35.139:1.11.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.
sn35.139:1.11.eng: Giving them up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.139:1.12.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yaṃ imasmiṃ jetavane tiṇakaṭṭha …pe…
sn35.139:1.12.eng: Suppose a person was to carry off the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in this Jeta’s Grove …

sn35.139:1.13.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, rūpā na tumhākaṃ; te pajahatha.
sn35.139:1.13.eng: In the same way, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas aren’t yours: give them up.

sn35.139:1.14.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissantī”ti ….
sn35.139:1.14.eng: Giving them up will be for your welfare and happiness.”

sn35.14:1.1.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn35.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

sn35.14:1.2.pli: ‘ko nu kho rūpānaṃ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?
sn35.14:1.2.eng: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sights …

sn35.14:1.7.pli: ko dhammānaṃ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan’ti?

sn35.14:1.9.pli: ‘yaṃ kho rūpe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ rūpānaṃ assādo.

sn35.14:1.10.pli: Yaṃ rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ rūpānaṃ ādīnavo.

sn35.14:1.11.pli: Yo rūpesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ.

sn35.14:1.16.pli: yaṃ dhamme paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ dhammānaṃ assādo.

sn35.14:1.17.pli: Yaṃ dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ dhammānaṃ ādīnavo.

sn35.14:1.18.pli: Yo dhammesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ dhammānaṃ nissaraṇan’ti.

sn35.14:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ channaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ evaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.

sn35.14:2.2.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ channaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ evaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.

sn35.14:2.4.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.

sn35.140:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo cakkhussa uppādāya, sopi anicco.
sn35.140:1.2.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to the eye is also impermanent.

sn35.140:1.3.pli: Aniccasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, cakkhu kuto niccaṃ bhavissati …pe…
sn35.140:1.3.eng: Since the eye is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?

sn35.140:1.5.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo jivhāya uppādāya sopi anicco.

sn35.140:1.6.pli: Aniccasambhūtā, bhikkhave, jivhā kuto niccā bhavissati …pe…

sn35.140:1.8.pli: Yopi, bhikkhave, hetu yopi paccayo manassa uppādāya, sopi anicco.
sn35.140:1.8.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to the mind is also impermanent.

sn35.140:1.9.pli: Aniccasambhūto, bhikkhave, mano kuto nicco bhavissati.
sn35.140:1.9.eng: Since the mind is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?

sn35.140:1.10.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati …pe… jivhāyapi nibbindati …pe… manasmimpi nibbindati,
sn35.140:1.10.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn35.140:1.11.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.140:1.11.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.140:1.12.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.140:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.141:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo cakkhussa uppādāya, sopi dukkho.
sn35.141:1.2.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to the eye is also suffering.

sn35.141:1.3.pli: Dukkhasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, cakkhu kuto sukhaṃ bhavissati …pe…
sn35.141:1.3.eng: Since the eye is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?

sn35.141:1.5.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo jivhāya uppādāya, sopi dukkho.

sn35.141:1.6.pli: Dukkhasambhūtā, bhikkhave, jivhā kuto sukhā bhavissati …pe…

sn35.141:1.8.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo manassa uppādāya, sopi dukkho.
sn35.141:1.8.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to the mind is also suffering.

sn35.141:1.9.pli: Dukkhasambhūto, bhikkhave, mano kuto sukho bhavissati.
sn35.141:1.9.eng: Since the mind is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?

sn35.141:1.11.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.142:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo cakkhussa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn35.142:1.2.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to the eye is also not-self.

sn35.142:1.3.pli: Anattasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, cakkhu kuto attā bhavissati …pe…
sn35.142:1.3.eng: Since the eye is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

sn35.142:1.5.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo jivhāya uppādāya, sopi anattā.

sn35.142:1.6.pli: Anattasambhūtā, bhikkhave, jivhā kuto attā bhavissati …pe…

sn35.142:1.8.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo manassa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn35.142:1.8.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to the mind is also not-self.

sn35.142:1.9.pli: Anattasambhūto, bhikkhave, mano kuto attā bhavissati.
sn35.142:1.9.eng: Since the mind is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

sn35.142:1.11.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.143:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo rūpānaṃ uppādāya, sopi anicco.
sn35.143:1.2.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to sights is also impermanent.

sn35.143:1.3.pli: Aniccasambhūtā, bhikkhave, rūpā kuto niccā bhavissanti.
sn35.143:1.3.eng: Since sights are produced by what is impermanent, how could they be permanent?

sn35.143:1.9.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo dhammānaṃ uppādāya, sopi anicco.
sn35.143:1.9.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to ideas is also impermanent.

sn35.143:1.10.pli: Aniccasambhūtā, bhikkhave, dhammā kuto niccā bhavissanti.
sn35.143:1.10.eng: Since ideas are produced by what is impermanent, how could they be permanent?

sn35.143:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.144:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo rūpānaṃ uppādāya, sopi dukkho.
sn35.144:1.2.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to sights is also suffering.

sn35.144:1.3.pli: Dukkhasambhūtā, bhikkhave, rūpā kuto sukhā bhavissanti.
sn35.144:1.3.eng: Since sights are produced by what is suffering, how could they be happiness?

sn35.144:1.9.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo dhammānaṃ uppādāya, sopi dukkho.
sn35.144:1.9.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to ideas is also suffering.

sn35.144:1.10.pli: Dukkhasambhūtā, bhikkhave, dhammā kuto sukhā bhavissanti.
sn35.144:1.10.eng: Since ideas are produced by what is suffering, how could they be happiness?

sn35.144:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.145:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo rūpānaṃ uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn35.145:1.2.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to sights is also not-self.

sn35.145:1.3.pli: Anattasambhūtā, bhikkhave, rūpā kuto attā bhavissanti.
sn35.145:1.3.eng: Since sights are produced by what is not-self, how could they be self?

sn35.145:1.9.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo dhammānaṃ uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn35.145:1.9.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to ideas is also not-self.

sn35.145:1.10.pli: Anattasambhūtā, bhikkhave, dhammā kuto attā bhavissanti.
sn35.145:1.10.eng: Since ideas are produced by what is not-self, how could they be self?

sn35.145:1.11.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpesupi nibbindati, saddesupi … gandhesupi … rasesupi … phoṭṭhabbesupi … dhammesupi nibbindati.

sn35.145:1.12.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.145:1.12.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.145:1.13.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.145:1.13.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.146:1.1.pli: “Navapurāṇāni, bhikkhave, kammāni desessāmi kammanirodhaṃ kammanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ.
sn35.146:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you old deeds, new deeds, the cessation of deeds, and the practice that leads to the cessation of deeds.

sn35.146:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmīti.
sn35.146:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak. …

sn35.146:1.4.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, purāṇakammaṃ abhisaṅkhataṃ abhisañcetayitaṃ vedaniyaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ …pe…
sn35.146:1.4.eng: The eye is old deeds. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
sn35.146:1.4.comm: That is to say, the fact that the eye exists is because we were born into this life driven by the deeds in past lives.

sn35.146:1.5.pli: jivhā purāṇakammā abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā vedaniyā daṭṭhabbā …pe…

sn35.146:1.6.pli: mano purāṇakammo abhisaṅkhato abhisañcetayito vedaniyo daṭṭhabbo.
sn35.146:1.6.eng: mind is old deeds. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.

sn35.146:1.9.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, etarahi kammaṃ karoti kāyena vācāya manasā,
sn35.146:1.9.eng: The deeds you currently perform by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn35.146:1.11.eng: And what is the cessation of deeds?

sn35.146:1.12.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, kāyakammavacīkammamanokammassa nirodhā vimuttiṃ phusati,
sn35.146:1.12.eng: When you experience freedom due to the cessation of deeds by body, speech, and mind.

sn35.146:1.13.eng: This is called the cessation of deeds.

sn35.146:1.14.eng: And what’s the practice that leads to the cessation of deeds?

sn35.146:1.15.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn35.146:1.16.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi—
sn35.146:1.16.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn35.146:1.17.eng: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of deeds.

sn35.146:1.18.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, desitaṃ mayā purāṇakammaṃ, desitaṃ navakammaṃ, desito kammanirodho, desitā kammanirodhagāminī paṭipadā.
sn35.146:1.18.eng: So, mendicants, I’ve taught you old deeds, new deeds, the cessation of deeds, and the practice that leads to the cessation of deeds.

sn35.146:1.19.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
sn35.146:1.19.eng: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

sn35.146:1.20.pli: Etāni, bhikkhave, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyatha, bhikkhave, mā pamādattha; mā pacchāvippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī”ti.
sn35.146:1.20.eng: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

sn35.147:0.3.eng: The Impermanent as Conducive to Extinguishment

sn35.147:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.

sn35.147:1.3.pli: katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā?
sn35.147:1.3.eng: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?

sn35.147:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuṃ aniccanti passati, rūpā aniccāti passati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ aniccanti passati, cakkhusamphasso aniccoti passati. Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti passati …pe…
sn35.147:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also impermanent.

sn35.147:1.5.pli: jivhā aniccāti passati, rasā aniccāti passati, jivhāviññāṇaṃ aniccanti passati, jivhāsamphasso aniccoti passati, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti passati …pe…
sn35.147:1.5.eng: They see that the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.147:1.6.pli: mano aniccoti passati, dhammā aniccāti passati, manoviññāṇaṃ aniccanti passati, manosamphasso aniccoti passati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti passati.
sn35.147:1.6.eng: mind, ideas, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also impermanent.

sn35.147:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā”ti.
sn35.147:1.7.eng: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”

sn35.148:0.3.eng: The Suffering as Conducive to Extinguishment

sn35.148:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.

sn35.148:1.3.pli: katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā?
sn35.148:1.3.eng: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?

sn35.148:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, cakkhuṃ dukkhanti passati, rūpā dukkhāti passati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dukkhanti passati, cakkhusamphasso dukkhoti passati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhanti passati …pe…
sn35.148:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are suffering. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also suffering.

sn35.148:1.5.eng: They see that the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.148:1.6.pli: mano dukkhoti passati, dhammā dukkhāti passati, manoviññāṇaṃ dukkhanti passati, manosamphasso dukkhoti passati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhanti passati.
sn35.148:1.6.eng: mind, ideas, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are suffering. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also suffering.

sn35.148:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā”ti.
sn35.148:1.7.eng: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”

sn35.149:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.

sn35.149:1.3.pli: katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā?
sn35.149:1.3.eng: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?

sn35.149:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuṃ anattāti passati, rūpā anattāti passati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattāti passati, cakkhusamphasso anattāti passati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattāti passati …pe…
sn35.149:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are not-self. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also not-self.

sn35.149:1.5.pli: mano anattāti passati, dhammā anattāti passati, manoviññāṇaṃ anattāti passati, manosamphasso anattāti passati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattāti passati.
sn35.149:1.5.eng: They see that the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind, ideas, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are not-self. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also not-self.

sn35.149:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā”ti.
sn35.149:1.6.eng: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”
